multiple-choice.question: What motivated the geologist to find the Titanic?

options.label: A
options.text: To find the lost city of Atlantis

options.label: B
options.text: To find the Thresher and Scorpion submarines

options.label: C
options.text: To find the Titanic as a Mount Everest in his world

options.label: D
options.text: To find the Titanic as a challenge

options.label: A
options.text: Because they thought it was too expensive

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were not interested in the Titanic

options.label: C
options.text: Because they wanted to keep the expedition classified

options.label: D
options.text: Because they thought it was too difficult

multiple-choice.question: What secret did the geologist learn that helped him find the Titanic?

options.label: A
options.text: The location of the Thresher and Scorpion submarines

options.label: B
options.text: The currents that carried the debris from the Titanic

options.label: C
options.text: The location of the Titanic's wreck

options.label: D
options.text: The time it took for the Titanic to sink

multiple-choice.question: What was the geologist's first impression of seeing the Titanic for the first time?

options.label: A
options.text: It was a bright and sunny day

options.label: B
options.text: It was a beautiful and peaceful experience

options.label: C
options.text: It was pitch black and then suddenly appeared

options.label: D
options.text: It was a sad and emotional experience

multiple-choice.question: What did the geologist and his team do after realizing they were standing on the Titanic's grave?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: They held a memorial service to honor the victims

options.label: C
options.text: They took a break to rest and recover

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: Approximately how many times do you breathe in per day?

options.label: B

options.label: D
options.text: To filter waste products from the blood

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: To increase the contact area between blood and oxygen

title: How do focus groups work? - Hector Lanz

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary goal of a focus group in market research?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide quantitative data on consumer behavior.

options.label: B
options.text: To generate new ideas for products and marketing based on deeper understanding of consumer habits.

options.label: C
options.text: To test the effectiveness of advertising campaigns.

options.label: D
options.text: To conduct in-depth interviews with a small sample size.

multiple-choice.question: Who coined the term "focus group"?
What is observer interference in the context of focus groups?

options.label: A
options.text: The influence of social pressure from the rest of the group on participant answers.

options.label: B
options.text: The impact of the researchers' presence on participant answers.

options.label: C
options.text: The effect of knowing that one is participating in a focus group on participant answers.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main limitation of focus groups?

options.label: A
options.text: The small sample size used in focus groups.

options.label: B
options.text: The presence of the researchers in the focus group.

options.label: C
options.text: The act of observing something can change it.

options.label: D
options.text: The findings from focus groups are often difficult to generalize.

multiple-choice.question: What is the typical size of a focus group?

title: Why do people get so anxious about math? - Orly Rubinsten

multiple-choice.question: What is the phenomenon experienced by some people when they take a math test, characterized by a faster heartbeat, sweating palms, and difficulty concentrating?
According to researchers, what percentage of the population suffers from math anxiety?
What is the cognitive resource that math anxiety decreases, leaving less available to tackle math tasks?
Why do some studies suggest that the way children are exposed to math by their parents and teachers plays a large part in math anxiety?

options.label: A
options.text: Because parents and teachers are not good at math

options.label: B
options.text: Because parents and teachers talk about math like something challenging and unfamiliar

options.label: C
options.text: Because parents and teachers are not interested in math

options.label: D
options.text: Because parents and teachers are too lenient

multiple-choice.question: What is the psychological principle that suggests the brain is flexible and the areas involved in math skills can always grow and develop?

title: What makes a poem … a poem? - Melissa Kovacs

multiple-choice.question: Muhammad Ali delivered a poem to Harvard's graduating class in 1975, which consisted of only two words: "Me, we." Or is it "me, weeee"? Regardless, what makes a poem a poem?

options.label: A
options.text: A poem is a machine that creates rhythm and rhyme.

options.label: B
options.text: A poem is a condensed form of language that expresses intense feelings.

options.label: C
options.text: A poem is a form of art that uses language to create new understandings and comment on human existence.

options.label: D
options.text: A poem is a song with a catchy melody.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is one characteristic of poetry that is often debated?

options.label: A
options.text: Whether poetry is a form of art or literature.

options.label: B
options.text: Whether poetry needs to be lyrical or can be visual.

options.label: D
options.text: Whether poetry can be created by machines.

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the form of poetry that uses vivid images and wordplay but is formatted like paragraphs?

According to the transcript, what is the result of Dartmouth researchers testing whether robots can pen poetry?

options.label: A
options.text: The robots were able to create sonnets that were indistinguishable from those written by humans.

options.label: B
options.text: The robots were able to create poetry that was more creative than that written by humans.

options.label: C
options.text: The robots were caught red-handed 100% of the time.

options.label: D
options.text: The robots were able to create poetry that was more emotional than that written by humans.

options.label: B
options.text: To eliminate the threat of communist subversion

options.label: C
options.text: To expose espionage by American communists

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: He was censured and his power diminished

options.label: C
options.text: He was appointed as the head of the FBI

options.label: D
options.text: He died shortly after the censure

title: What happened to trial by jury? - Suja A. Thomas

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what percentage of criminal cases in the US are decided by juries today?
What is the main reason why the number of guilty pleas has increased in the US from around 20% to 90% between the 19th and 21st centuries?

options.label: A
options.text: The increase in the number of crimes committed

options.label: B
options.text: The risk of a greater prison sentence after a trial

options.label: C
options.text: The introduction of new technologies in the justice system

options.label: D
options.text: The decrease in the number of trials

multiple-choice.question: What is summary judgement, and what is its intended purpose?

options.label: A
options.text: Summary judgement is a procedure that allows judges to decide cases without a trial, and it is intended to speed up the justice process.

options.label: B
options.text: Summary judgement is a procedure that allows judges to decide cases without a trial, and it is intended only for cases where no reasonable jury would disagree.

options.label: C
options.text: Summary judgement is a procedure that allows juries to decide cases without a judge, and it is intended to increase the power of the judiciary.

options.label: D
options.text: Summary judgement is a procedure that allows defendants to plead guilty without a trial, and it is intended to reduce the number of trials.

multiple-choice.question: What is arbitration, and how is it often agreed to?

options.label: A
options.text: Arbitration is a procedure that allows juries to decide cases without a judge, and it is often agreed to by parties in a contract.

options.label: B
options.text: Arbitration is a procedure that allows judges to decide cases without a trial, and it is often agreed to by parties in a contract.

options.label: C
options.text: Arbitration is a procedure that allows parties to resolve their disputes through a professional arbitrator, and it is often agreed to unwittingly when people sign contracts like employment applications and consumer agreements.

options.label: D
options.text: Arbitration is a procedure that allows defendants to plead guilty without a trial, and it is often agreed to by parties in a contract.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what are some advantages of juries in the US justice system?

options.label: A
options.text: Juries are cheap and efficient, and they always make the right decision.

options.label: B
options.text: Juries are more representative of the general population and don't have the same incentives as prosecutors, legislators, or judges seeking reelection or promotion.

options.label: C
options.text: Juries are only necessary in complex cases, and they are always necessary in civil cases.

options.label: D
options.text: Juries are only necessary in criminal cases, and they are always necessary in cases where the defendant is guilty.

title: What happens during a heart attack? - Krishna Sudhir

multiple-choice.question: What is the main cause of a heart attack?

options.label: B
options.text: Fatty deposits on the walls of coronary arteries

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary symptom of a heart attack?

options.label: B
options.text: Chest pain caused by the oxygen-deprived heart muscle

multiple-choice.question: What is the recommended treatment for a heart attack in the emergency room?

options.label: A
options.text: Taking aspirin and nitroglycerin to keep the heart attack from getting worse

options.label: B
options.text: Performing surgery to reopen the blocked artery

options.label: C
options.text: Using a blood test to diagnose a heart attack

options.label: D
options.text: Performing an electrocardiogram to measure the heart's electrical activity

multiple-choice.question: What are some lifestyle changes that can help lower the risk of heart attacks?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Smoking and consuming high amounts of sugar

options.label: C
options.text: Avoiding tobacco use and staying fit

options.label: D
options.text: Consuming high amounts of saturated fats and red meat

title: How small are we in the scale of the universe? - Alex Hofeldt

options.label: B

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: The image covers a small portion of the night sky, equivalent to one two-millionth of the total area

options.label: C

options.label: D

multiple-choice.question: How many galaxies were captured in the eXtreme Deep Field image (XDF)?

options.label: C

multiple-choice.question: What can we learn about the universe from the Deep Field images?

options.label: A

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: The universe is static and has not changed over time

options.label: D
options.text: The universe is finite and has a definite boundary

title: Would winning the lottery make you happier? - Raj Raghunathan

multiple-choice.question: According to a famous study, what happened to the reported levels of happiness of 22 lottery winners months after winning?

options.label: B
options.text: Their average reported levels of happiness increased no more than that of a control group.

options.label: C
options.text: Their average reported levels of happiness decreased significantly.

options.label: D
options.text: Their average reported levels of happiness remained the same.

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: We revert to our default emotional state.

options.label: C
options.text: We become more emotionally sensitive to change.

options.label: D
options.text: We become less adaptable to new situations.

multiple-choice.question: What study found that people who donated tended to be happier than those who didn't?

options.label: B
options.text: A study of people who had suffered an accident that left them paralyzed

options.label: C
options.text: A study of over 200,000 people from 136 countries

options.label: D
options.text: A study of people who had won a game of monopoly

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is a more effective way to turn your money into happiness?

options.label: A

options.label: B
